div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for [PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from SUAKIN every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves SUEZ for JEDDAH continuing every other week for SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond JEDDAH but call at TOR (for SINAI) EL WEDJ and YAMBO as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.

div.head: LIBERALS AND FOREIGN POLICY
div.p: Commenting upon the foreign policy of the Liberal Government, the "Outlook" says: — There is too much reason to believe that neither in the Cabinet nor in the Liberal party generally is Sir Edward Grey receiving that rapport which is necessary for the successful accomplishment of his task. If we had not already known that there was a Potsdam party in the Cabinet, we should have learned the fact from the amazing article on the relations between England and Germany in the September number of the "Deutsche Revue." The leaders of that party, as the "Deutsche Revue" accurately states, are the Lord Chancellor and Mr. Haldane, and it is to be feared that, if not already the larger party in the Cabinet, it may become so. There are, more over, not wanting signs of what looks suspiciously like a concerted movement against Sir Edward Grey on the part of a certain section of Liberals.... Sir Edward Grey has, it is true, committed himself to statements in regard to disarmament which have been taken by the foreign Press generally as a consession to the exigencies of the party position .... We have at last found a foreign policy, and, if we allowed ourselves to be diverted from it by a sentimental desire for 'hands all round' and a fatuous attempt to maintain equally close and amicable relations with countries whose interests are fundamentally opposed, we should only finally confirm the opinion, which we have with difficulty succeeded in eradicating to some extent from the minds of other nations, that as friends or allies we are untrustworthy and useless. That would certainly be the opinion in France if the English people allowed the present Government to yield to the mingled threats and blandishments of Berlin… No party desires to quarrel with Germany …But all who are willing to see things as they are, and not merely as they would have them to be, know that the best, if not the only, way to preserve peace is to make it impossible for Germany to attack us, on the one hand, by maintaining our Army and Navy at the highest point of efficiency, on the other hand, by maintaining and extending our alliances. The aims of Germany are stated by the semi-official mouth pieces of the German Government with a frankness which suggests that they have a poor opinion of British intelligence. If the persons of advanced democratic and Radical sympathies in this country, who, with an unaccountable perversity, prefer Prussian Caecarism to the French Republic, are not convinced by the "Deutsche Revue" of the worse than folly of their overtures to Germany, other recent events may help them to conviction. The intrinsic importance at the election of a German to be General of the Society of Jesus has, perhaps, been somewhat exaggerated by the French Press………… The real significance of the election of Father Wernz is the indication that it gives to the world in regard to the political Policy of the rulers of the Roman Catholic Church. We cannot agree with the opinion expressed by many French newspapers, and even by the "Temps" that this election is a great gain to German interests, and a corresponding loss to those of France. On the contrary, it is an immense advantage that the real situation should be forced on the notice of those who have hitherto ignored it. The German Emperor is a greater danger to the peace of Europe than fifty Jesuit Generals, and the German Emperor has long been with us. It would be deplorable from the national point of view if Sir Edward Grey, like Lord Palmerston, were driven from the Foreign Office by a cabal against him in the Cabinet, even if he changed it (as might, in certain circumstances, be possible for the leadership of the House of Commons. It would be still more deplorable if he allowed himself to be over ruled by those whom the "Deuttsche Revue" describes as very 'Germanophil Ministers,' and induced to adopt a policy which his own better judgment would condemn. We cannot regard the latter contingency as possible. We are convinced that Sir Edward Gray would resign rather then endanger the Anglo-French understanding by responding to the clumsy wiles of Berlin."

div.head: Authorizations to Practice.
div.p: Mrs. Filippa Procida, mid-wife, and M. Philppe Steph Nicoglou, doctor, have been authorized to practise in Egypt.
The Kassaia Line
The "Sudan Times" says that the work of joining the Kassala and Berber-Port Sudan line will commence early next year.
The Plague
A fatal case occurred at Suez yesterday and one fresh case was admitted to hospital there. There are no fresh cases at Alexandria.
New Bank at Cairo.
It is reported that the Societe Generale for the development of commerce and industry intends to open shortly a branch at Cairo.
Egyptian Nationalism
Among the articles in the October "Independent Review" will be "The New Egyptian Nationalism," by Mr, Wilfrid Scawen Blunt.
Club des Ecoles.
The Club des Ecoles supérieures, Cairo, removes today to premises in the Daira el Khassa. Rue Kamel, in front of Esbekieh Gardens.
Pensions to Retiring Ministers.
According to a new regulation to be submitted to the Council of Ministers a yearly pension of £700 will be granted to every retiring Minister.
Telephone Company, Ltd.
In consequence of alterations in the telephone service between Alexandria and Ramleh, the night service on that line will be discontinued from Saturday to Monday.
Land in Cairo.
The price of land has still an upward tendency. Within the last fortnight several important plots have been sold in choice quarters of Cairo at very high prices.
Registration of Births and Deaths.
The General Administration of the Sanitary Service is elaborating a new regulation for the registration of births and deaths, to apply equally to local and foreign subjects.
The Pyramids Murder
Nicolas Mogabgah, the murderer of Abou Samat, nazir of Soliman Bey, has at last been, arrested in an hotel at Cairo. Nicolas was, it is stated, an ex volunteer in the British Army.
Sudan Budget.
Lewa Bernard Pasha, financial secretary of the Sudan Government, will draw up the Sudan Budget for 1907 at Cairo during October and November, and will return to Khartoum in December.
The Cairo Tramways
The Cairo Tramway Co has under consideration a scheme of modification for the Soubry line, which will connect that square with Bab- el Hadid, the Ismailieh Canal, Ataba-el-Hadra. and Old Cairo.
The Brindisi Mail.

The G.P.O., Alexandria, will accept ordinary correspondence for transmission by the Brindisi mail up to 3.10 p m on Monday and registered letters up to 2.10 pm. Insured articles and money orders must be handed in by noon on the same day snd parcels before 6 p.m. on Sunday.
Weather at Suez.

Our Suez correspondent writes:- Since the beginning of September the weather at Seuz was exceptionally cool, and everybody thought the warm weather was over. However these last few days the heat has been very great, and kamseen-like winds are blowing making the atmosphere exceedingly thick and hot.
The Loquacious Wattman.

An incident is reported from the Maidan Al Ashar. A tram, the wattman of which was apparently enjoying a chat, ran into a cart and horse on Tuesday afternoon, injuring the horse and smashing the cart. A long argument followed accompanied by theatric and gesticulation on the part of the justly offended carrier, till the passengers, conceiving that they might otherwise remain in the tram till nightfall, called on the police, who took the wettman's number and conducted the carter to the caracol.
Military News.

In to-day's issues of a Cairo morning newspaper appears the following information: "The 3rd battalion of the Coldstream Guards which arrived on Wednesday last at Alexandria, is leaving for Suez to carry out maneuvers." This battalion has been noted for remarkable feats, and, if we are to believe our contemporary, it is now possessed of the power, hitherto considered ungrauted, of being in the two places at once. The battalion will embark to-morrow at Southampton for Alexandria, as previously announced.
Fire at Damanhour

Over Damanhour correspondent writes -A serious fire broke out in the newly built house of El Bonus, a native merchant of this town about nine o'clock tonight (Thursday) owing to a lamp falling on to a mass of wood chippings. The attention of the passersby was attracted by the loud screams of the women in the house and the fire brigade was quickly summoned to the scene. After battling with the flames for more than a couple of hours the conflagration was got under, but not before a good deal of damage had been done.

Mr. Taft has issued an ultimatum to the disputants threatening the establishment by America of a military Government in Cuba unless they listened to reason. The Government has hurriedly consented to negotiate with the rebels and will leave the disputed points to the arbitration of Mr. Taft. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE KING IN ABERDEEN.
RECEPTION AT THE UNIVERSITY.

div.p: The King and Queen had a most enthusiastic reception at Aberdeen. Enormous crowds witnessed the procession along decorated streets to the University. 5,000 people filled the quadrangle where King Edward performed the ceremony of opening the new buildings. (Reuter)

div.head:
WEST AUSTRALIAN ASSEMBLY
STATE UNION DETRIMENTAL

div.p: The West Australian Assembly resolved that the union of the State with the rest of the Commonwealth was detrimental to West Australia. The time had arrived for submitting to the people the question of withdrawal from the Union. (Reuter)

div.head:
BRITISH BRAVERY AT TUAREG.
SIX BRITISHERS DRIVE OFF 500 NATIVES

div.p: According to news received from Lake Tched. extraordinary bravery has been shown by 6 British native soldiers commanded by a native corporal. They resisted prolonged and determined attacks from 500 natives of Tuareg, and finally drove them off with heavy loss. (Reuter)

div.head:
SIRDAR'S RETURN
INTERVIEW WITH THE KING

div.p: Major General Sir Reginald Wingats will leave on Saturday for Cairo. He has been summoned to Balmoral by the King to-day. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE RUSSIAN ATROCITIES
LADY ARRESTED AT PETERHOF

div.p: General Kaulbars added that in the event of the assassination of even one member of the "Union of the Russian People" the city would be inundated with blood. (Reuter)
New arrests have been effected at Peterhof, notably that of a lady who was taken to the St. Petersburg fortress under a strong escort. (Reuter)

div.head: MANNHEIM SOCIALIST CONGRESS. HERR BEBEL's SPEECH.

div.p: At the Socialist Congress, which is being held at Mannheim, Herr Bebal caused a sensation by a speech declaring that the proclamation of a general strike throughout Germany, used as a weapon to obtain reforms or in the event of the Government intervening against the Russian Revolution, would be impossible becuase it would be doomed to failure (Reuter)

div.head:
INTERNATIONAL CANCER CONFERENCE
Foundation of International Congress

div.p: At the International Cancer Conference, met here, it has been resolved to found an international society with the object of combatting this disease. (Reuter)

The Institute of International Law adopted articles prohibiting the use of wireless telegraphy by neutrals in a belligerent zone. Such neutrals is captured would be treated as prisoners of war and their ships and balloons might be confiscaed. The sewing of fixed or floating mines in the high seas is prohibited. (Reuter)
South Africa v. East Midlands. South Africa won by 37 points to nil. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
div.p: "AL LEWA" APOLOGISES.
THE ATTACK ON THE SYRIANS.

"Al Lewa'' has now earned — and with justice -the bitter resentment of the Syrians resident in Egypt. After a violent anti Syrian polemic Mustapha Pasha Kamel's organ has attempted an excuse by explaining that it only referred to "turbulent persons of low origin" (who have evidently represented their nation in the eyes of the aristocratic journalists of the Nationalist Press). Representatives of "Al Lewa" have made their apologies at the bureaux of the principal Syrian journals in Cairo and have been pardoned in view of the extraordinary ignorance they hare manifested on the subject.

Our Nationalist contemporaries would carry more weight among persons of education and good breeding did they avoid the reckless personalities and misinformed generalisations relating to their opponents which dishonorably distinguish their columns. We recommend these reflections to the last edition "Al Omma" now in gaol for assisting a nephew to impersonate his uncle and thereby obtain £80 from the Post Offices.

div.head: "LEWA" AND MOAYAD"
div.p: Although some of our publicists speak of the "Pan Islamic" party or of the "Nationalists" of Egypt in terms that would suggest a united and well-disciplined organisation -a veritable band of brothers, - those who are in touch with native "politics"—if the word can be employed to describe a curious combination of fanaticism, intrigue, and self advertisement —are aware that the harmony said to exist among the Moslem politicians of the country is curiously hard to discover. We recently described an ingenious attempt to injure the political and journalistic reputation of Abu Shadi Bey, editor of Al Zahar," who was accused of the heinous offense of seeking an interview with Mr M. de C. Findlay, C.M.G. noting British Agent and Consul General. The attempt appears to have failed - at all events, the public has lost interest in it, and watches with some ammusement the signs of an approaching struggle between the protagonists of Pan-Islamism. Sheikh Ali Youssaf, editor of "Al Moayed," and Mustapha Pasha Kamel, editor of "Al Lewa"

Within the last three weeks "Al Moayad" - which has in the past had sundry skirmishes, with its rival, published articles in which the ' Nationalist leader' same in for some severe , criticism. We need not ask whether the learned sheikk's programme differed or differs to any considerable extent from that of the redoubtable Pasha, or whether the Patriot's annoyance. The world which is as sadly prone to cynicism at Cairo as anywhere else remarked with relish that the Sheikh and his following had grown rather tired of hearing about the Kaiser and the Khalif, the Egyptian patriot and the largest circulation among Moslem papers, and had they known the play would doubtless have expressed their sympathy with the first lion of the pair celebrate in "Bombastes Furioso" who after roaring with great vigour and fullness of tone was outroared by a rival:

"Thus I have heard on Afric's sunny shore Another lion gives a louder roar: And the first lion thought the last a bore." But is this case the second lion had claws, and "Al Moayad" had roared two or three times in answer to "Al Lewa's" bellowing. A number of Nationalist Vigilantes called upon Sheikh Ali Yussef, and after compliments explained their errand. The shell of politeness, to use an Oriental figure, enclosed the kernel of menace, and the Sheikh was urged to discontinue his criticisms of the Pasha on the ground that his list of subscribers would otherwise be diminished. The interview over the counsellors departed, and "Al Moayad" ceased to criticism. We wonder how long the silence thus forcibly imposed upon Sheikh Ali Youssef and his collaborators will be allowed to remain unbroken.

div.head: "A CELEBRATED IRISHMAN."
div.p: From "Al Wattan":-

All the world knows that the Irish are the indomitable enemies of England, and that their politics are invariably antagonistic to British politics. The mere fact of the influential members of the Municipality of Dublin lowering the British flag at their ceremonies, and refusing to drink the King's Health at their banquets, shows us, even by itself, all the animosity of Irishmen, and all the hatred that they have vowed against England. We personally know of one Irishman who is celebrated for his vituperation, and his meddling with Egyptian affairs, and he is Mr. Wilfried Blent, who has just written a book on "The atrocities of justice under the British Occupation of Egypt." Moreover several of our contemporaries have undertaken the translation of this work and its publication in their columns, without fully realizing that by falling into the views of an Irishman they are épée facto declaring their enmity to Great Britain. We would gladly draw their attention to all the wrong that they are about to do to the entire nation, if they persist in following this course, and also to the fact that it was they themselves who declared it inopportune to show themselves openly hostile to England, and that their adherence to the criticisms and attacks of Mr. Blunt may very well destroy the fruit of many years of persevering efforts.

div.head: TRIESTE HARBOUR.
div.p: THE NEW WORKS.
The commercial relations between Alexandria and Trieste are developing every year and the new harbour scheme at the great Austrian port is therefore of considerable interest to Egypt.

The old port of Trieste, along with the harbour added of late years, has become insufficient to meet actual requirements. Moreover, the "Bora" or N.E.E. wind, often blowing 80 miles an hour, frequently prevents ships coming in and out for whole days together. So in 1897 the Austrian Parliament voted a scheme providing for an improvement of the old port and the construction of a new one in the Gulf of Muggia, commonly known as "the natural port of Trieste," which is sheltered from the Bora wind by the adjoining mountains. The works were begun in 1900, and are proceeding so satisfactorily as to justify the hope generally entertained that this new harbour will be opened not long after the inauguration of the new railways connecting Trieste with the capital and with Germany by shorter routes. The new port and the new railways, it is confidently hoped, will give fresh impulse to the transit trade of Trieste, which will be brought to about ten hours distance from Bavaria instead of twenty- eight, thus becoming an easier port for Germany, if not "a German port," as it has been called.

The trade of Trieste, which in the decade 1860-1870 represented 11 1/2 per cent of the aggregate trade of Trieste, Venice, Fiume, Genoa, Marseilles, Bremen, and Hamburg, fell during the period 1890-98 to 6 1/2 per cent. Subsequently, there was an improvement. From 1898 to 1902 the total tonnage of ships entering Trieste rose from 2,060,000 tons to 2,5000,000 tons. The traffic in port rose from 956,000 to 1,240,000 ton.s The port extension works will necessitate an outlay of 4 /12 millions sterling for the new (Muggier) harbour, plus one million sterling for widening the quays of the old port and building a new stone pier. The new harbour comprises and area of 1,600 meters in length, and 330 in width, having three piers each 160 meters in width and 360, 513, and 778 metres respectively in length, protected by three breakwaters, via, two 500 meters and one 1,600 meters in length. A vote of 4,000,000 has just been granted by Parliament for the new works, and a resolution has been passed enjoining the Government to hasten their completion.
The following figures will give the reader a fair idea of the importance of the new harbour as compared with the old one:-

The actual transit trade of this port is 78 per cent of the total trade of Trieste, hence special provision has been made for this branch of trade in the plan of the new harbour; the hangars (sheds) being three times those of the old ones. The increase of warehouses for goos in transit will be 300 per cent., whilst the increase of the general warehouses will be more than 120 per cent.

The insufficiency of hangars (sheds) having been greatly felt lately, special care will be given to a new system providing adequate hauling power. There will be 22 hangars, each 45 meters in width and 120-207 (average 150) in length, the largest housing 9000 tons goods. These hangars will be provided with 12 cranes for 3 tons, 85 for 1 1/2 tons, and a main crane for 50 tons. A new departure from general Methods in the transit of goods in the hangars will be made by the construction of an elevated, or upper level, thus facilitating the traction of goo is along the hangars- those on the upper level being outward bound, whilst inward-bound goods will be carried along the lower level way. Along the quays there is no danger from overcrowding, large cranes being available for both floors. ON the land side an elevated railway on iron piles will be used for goods on the upper floor of the hangars. The assorting station will be joined with the elevated railway by means of an inclined way. Buildings for custom-house, police, port, pilots, restaurants, etc., will also be provided. All cranes, hoists, capstans, and other machinery will be driven by electric power, furnished by a special power station.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss Liner Manepthah sailed from Liverpool on Thursday, and is due here on or about the 11th October, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss Liner Seti arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. Roman Prince left Malta on the 27th inst., with passengers and general cargo and is due to arrive at Alexandria on the 1st October.
The S.S. Sailor Prince left London on the 27th. inst. with passengers and general cargo and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 13th October.
The S.S. City of Oxford, now loading for Liverpool, will sail for that port in a few days. First class accommodation 14.
The Khedivial express mail steamship Ismailia will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Wednesday for Pireuva, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS
div.p: To the Editor or the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—The last two letters which have Appeared in your estimable paper under the Above trading here afforded vast entertainment to Officials and to all the "Common Commercial Herd" alike. The first of these two letters was an obvious "draw," which proved singularly successful. No sensible reader of that letter could have supposed the writer to have been really guilty of such vulgarity and lack of good taste as to deliberately insult the large and respected commercial class of Englishmen in this country.

"Another 20 year's resident, but not an official" rose promptly to the bait! In accusing the previous writer of lack of taste, of being obviously an official, and of having "received a fairly good board school education," does he not stand convicted of snobbishness?

The great majority—and a growing one— of the Civil servants in this country have had the privilege, or the misfortune, of having enjoyed a public school and 'Varsity training. I feel sure that most of these will agree with me in confessing how frequently they have had to regret the fact that they never had the benefit of a board school education with its far more practical and sensible training. Moreover, refinement is no more the result of a Varsity and public school training than is the lack of it the result of being taught at a board school. Refinement is a gift of nature, and where it does not exist originally, no kind of subsequent training will produce more than a very spurious form of that virtue which will quickly disappear in any crisis.

I will conclude by remarking that I have hitherto been under the impression that officials out here were members of the Egyptian Civil Service and civilians just as much as the "common herd" "Civilians" are only so called to distinguish them from their military brethren whom we are told we ape with so little success!
"A Civilian Official."
Medinet el Fayoum, September 27th. 1906.

div.head: EDUCATION OF THE POOR.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir.—I have the honour to draw your kind attention to a serious matter which, if neglected, will deal a deadly blow to the education of the poor in our city.

A few notables have for long been accustomed to establish charitable schools under the name of Orwa Wosks, and their work has been entirely successful. Lavish subscriptions from the rich have been granted for that purpose. There were capable headmasters managing the schools, which were om the tame level with those of the Government. Fifty per cent of the people who joined the schools were without money. Schools and kuttahs under the name of Orwa Wosks were scattered in every part of the city and all the pupils of Alexandria, I daresay, joined these schools. No other native schools existed beside. The members of this society, who wore controlling the works of these schools by themselves, gave up the reins of education to other hands.

The great work of the director of these schools was to abate the expenses of the society. He brought teachers from the streets with humble pay. So he was, in the eyes of the members who do not check their work, a capable man acting for the good of the society.
A few days ago, the society issued an order, owing to the report of the director, to dismiss all non paying pupils. There was no reason at all. The society is still rich.
Where are the estates entailed by the Menshawi for the education of the poor?
We draw the attention of our reformers to this matter as well as to the great number of pupils who will be driven out from the schools, and will stray afterwards in the streets without work.—
Your obedient servant, A Moslem
Alexandria, September 25

div.head: THE CALEDONIA REFLOATED
div.p: Suez, Thursday.
The P & O. steamer Caledonia was refloated yesterday morning after having discharged a considerable lot of cargo. The vessel apparently sustained no damage whatever.

div.head: THE SULTAN AS A PATIENT.
div.p: The Sultan of Turkey has often shown himself to be one of the Peculiar People- perhaps the most peculiar of the lot. In his present hour of suffering he leaves no doubt of his loyally to the principles of the sect. He is what the doctors call an impossible patient. Submission to the slightest operation never enters, his head, or, at least, if it is put there by one of his learned medical attendants he makes the undertaking impossible by refusing to have chloroform administered. We have not heard how his Majesty takes medicine, but we doubt the most expensive sweetmeats will not lure him to a dose. Such a patient would dishearten any conscientious physician, and it is therefore not surprising that Progessor von Bergman has left Constantinople in despair. Peculiar people are never popular with doctors, and get little sympathy from the rest of the world. When they happen to be Sultans their case becomes hopeless. (Sr. James' Gazette)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We are authorized to state that the announcement made in to-day's issue of a Cairo morning newspaper to the effect that Earl of Cromer is expected to arrive in Egypt by the P. & O. steamer on the 9th October, is incorrect. Lord Cromer is expected to arrive about the 15th pros.
Lord Edward Cecil has left Cairo for Alexandria.
It is expected that Sir Vincent Corbett whose return to Egypt was fixed for the 6th prox., will arrive later than that date.
Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha is expected to arrive at Alexandria on Monday next on his return from Austria.
Dr Comanos Pasha has returned to Cairo after three months in Europe.
Lt. Col Garner has returned from leave and is acting as head of the Public Health Department in the absence of Sir H Pinching.
Dr. Milton, who was unexpectedly detained in England by the sudden iilness of his son, leaves Marseilles to-day by the S.S. "Persia," due at Port Said next Tuesday.
Mr. Critchley, the Manager of the Imperial Ottoman Bank at Alexandria, is leaving for a short visit to Europe by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Habsburg to morrow afternoon.
H.I.M. the Sultan has conferred the order of Osmanieh of the 2nd class on Sayid Hussein El- Kassabi, a notable of Gharbieh.

Count Anthony Stadnicki, Austro-Hungarian Charge-d'Affaires at Cairo, and M. Emile Weillunachey, secretary of the same Agency, who have spent the summer at Alexandria, will return to the Capital next week.
The "Tampa" announces the death of Mme Marguerite Olagnier, the composer, at the age of sixty-two years. She was the widow of Olagnier Bey, who at one time was very prominent in Egyptian politics.

The following announcement of appointments of Bachelors of Science (B.Sc.) in the Department of Agriculture, Edinburg, has been made:- John Bayna, M.A., manager of the Cotton Company of Rhodenia, P. Joannides manager of the estates of George Zervudachi, Egypt, and Sydney Pennington, M.R.C.V.S., Lecturer on Veterinary Medicine and Surgery, School of Agriculture, Ghizeh, Egypt.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR.
div.p: ALTERATIONS AT MEX.

It is announced in the "Official Journal" that Mex high lighthouse is about to be changed in the following manner:- A large hall and spike will be placed on the top of the lighthouse; the height from the bottom of the pedestal holding the ball, to the top of the spike being seventeen feet. Two substantial galleries will be placed round the lighthouses, each gallery being just below the windows from which the lights are exhibited. The work has been commenced, and will be completed in three weeks' time. The building of a new front leading light for the Great Pass will shortly be commenced at Mex.

The casino will he demolished about the end of November, 1906, and the work on the new lighthouse commenced immediately afterwards, in the same place. The new lighthouse will be about 70 feet high, colored with red and white horizontal stripes, and will carry three fixed lights, vertical red, white, red.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PORTS
div.p: One of the most interesting and instructive of the regular complications regarding the commerce and progress of Egypt is the quarterly review published by the statistical department of the Ministry of Finance, and giving the quarterly return of navigation in the ports of Egypt and the Suez Canal. The numerous statistical tables which the review gives are chiefly deducted from information provided by the Quarantine Board, but as regards passengers embarked on vessels clearing from the ports of Egypt, neither the Ports and Lights Administration nor the Board of Quarantine is able to obtain any information. The statistical department has therefore been compelled to have recount to the various shipping agencies and Consulates for information regarding passengers leaving the ports of Egypt, asking them at the same time to supply the necessary data concerning goods embarked and landed, in order to obtain some idea of the maritime commerce in the Egyptian ports. "It is to be much regretted." remarks M. Randoni, director of the department, in his preface to the tables, "that some agencies, fortunately very few, have not acceded to the request of this office for information and it is consequently incomplete. The data concerning passengers embarked have been published, for they proximate closely to the troth. As regards the movement of goods, information being very deficient, it is impossible to give data of any value- I would express the hope that those shipping agencies which have not so far supplied this department with the desired information, may appreciate the importance of the inquiries undertaken in this publication and in the future supply, with increasing accuracy, the data necessary for their completion."

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, le 27 Septembre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est toujours à 3 3/8 pour cent. Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a reperdu 1/8 à 86 3/8. L'Unifiée a clôturé in variée à 104 1/2. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 à 26 3/4. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 3/4, de même que la Daïra à 16 3/4 et la Delta Light à 11 1/2.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien progressé de 3 francs à 782 et la Banque d'Athènes de 1 franc à 145.
Ici, noue avoue eu, ce marin, un bon marché avec des cours soutenue et eu avance eu l'ensemble de la cote à quelques exceptions près.
La National Bank a gagné 1/16 à 26 9/16-5,8 L'Agricole a été ferme à 9 11/16. Le Comptoir Financier a progressé à 6 1/2 9/16 l'action ancienne et 6 5/16-3/8 la nouvelle.
Le Crédit Foncier a atteint 780 1/2 pour finir à 779 780. Lu Daîra a bénéficié de 1/16 à 16 7/8.
La Nile Land a avancé de 1/8 à 14 3/4. La part de fondateur Immobilière est remontée à 735. L'action Agricole du Nil est revenue à 264-265; la part de fondateur a réactionné à 8.

Les actions Entreprises Immobilières et Tra va or sa sont raffermies à 4 8/16 11 et la pari de fondateur à 69. L'action Enterprise and Development s'est alourdie à 12 8/6-7/16 par contre, la part de fondateur s'est inscrite a 33. Le Wardan Estate a rétrogradé à 7.
L'action Allotment a été mieuz tenne à 3 5/16 3/8 et la part de fondateur à 126 137 L'Union Foncière s'est consolidée à 6 1/16.

La Delta Light a fait 11 11/16 et la Ramleh 7 5/16. Les privilégiées Tramways d'Alex andrie ont fléchi à 185 et les Dividendes à 338 Les parts de fondateur Automobile ont baisse à 10 1/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont molli à 265 Les Héliopolis ont été demandés à 317.

Dans le groupe des valeurs bôtelières, les Nungovich ont été échangés à 17 5/16 l'action ancienne et 17 1/4 le nouvelle. Les Egyptien se sont maintenus à 6 3/16 1/4 Les Upper Egypt ont faibli à 4 11/16-3/4. Las National ont été ramenés de 4 à 3 13/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, il y a eu un bon mouvement ter les Delta Land, qui ont clôturé à 8 7/16, acheteurs. Lee Hooker ont été traités entre 0 19/16 et 1.

D'après une information provenant de source autorisée, le conseil d'administration de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. aurait décidé le paiement d'en coupon intérimaire de 10 %, c'est à-dire deux shellings par action. dans le cours de mots prochain, après publication d'un rapport détaillé pour les six premiers mois de l'exercice commença le 1er Avril 1906.

D'safre part, on procéderait, vert le fia Novembre, à la vente aux enchères publiques de 250 lots de terrain de construction,.représentant une superficie d'environ 125,000 mètres carrés, ris à Bernha, à proximité de quartier européen de la ville.
Lotis, avec tous frais compris, ces terrains ne reviendraient à la Société qu'a P.E.S. le mètre. Or, des offres ont été déjà faites aux santons de P.E. 75.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Londres, se date da 20 Septembre, le passage suivent:
"Les demandes d'or de l'Amérique com u appréhende plus que la Banque d'Angleterre soit obligée de portée son taux d'escompte à 4 1/2 pour cent.

"D'ailleurs, l'intervention de Trésor américain mettent immédiatement à la disposition des Banques des sommes égales au montent qe'elles ont commandé à l'étranger a produit un effet sensible sur les conditions monéteires à New York. Le bilan des Banques associées publié samedi pâmé, montre un changement considerable dans la situation.

"Néanmoias, la Banque d'Angleterre doit taire toujours bonne gards, bien que se réserve représente pieu de 47% des engagements, car on s'attend encore à de nouvelles et importantes demandes de la part de l'Egypte. Il flotte done tonjours au Stock Exchange une incertitude qui corn mas de à le spéculation de se tenir sur une certaine réserve."

Suivant des informations d*eParis, le délai pour l'échange des titres de la Sociéte des Sucreries et Rsffiuere d'Egypte, délai expirant le 20 Septembre courant, a été prorogé jusqu'à le fin de l'année.

Carnet de l'actionaire. Leu détenteurs de certificats provisoires d'actions de la Banque d'Orient qui n'sursient pas échangé leurs certificate contre des titres définitifs jusqu'au 30 Septembre courant, sout informés que cet échange se pour s'effectuer, à partir da 1er Octobre prochain, qu'aux guichets du siège central à Athènes, cu les certificats devront être expédiés aux frais des intéressés.

div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
Très peu d'affaires encore aujourd'hui et les cours en général demeurent stationnaires. Les transactions ont porté spécialement sur la Delta Lend et le Comptoir.
L'Agricole fléchit de 9 11/16 à 9 91/33, la National Bank de 26 9/16 à 26 7/16. la Cassa di Sconto de 222 1/4 à 222 l'ancienne, de 216 1/4 à 216 la nouvelle et les Sucreries de 27 à 25 1/2.

Par contre, la Béhéra hausse de 36 3/8 à 36 1/2, la Banque d'Athènes de 144 à 144 3/4. les Nungovich Hotels de 17 1/4 à 17 5/16, la Delta Land de 3 7/16 à 6 9/32, et le Comptoir de 6 1/9 4 6 19/39 l'ancienne, de 6 9/32 à 6 3/8 la nouvelle et de 42 à 43 la part de fondateur.
Comme on le voit, la cote fait preuve de beaucoup de fermeté et l'on s'attend à une reprise sérieuse dès qu'il nous viendra quelque encouragement du dehors.

div.head: SOCIETE GENERALE DES
div.p: Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte Siege Social Au Caire

Par decision de l'Assemblèe Gènèrale extraordinaire des Actionaires, tenue a Caire la 24 Mars 1906, le Capital nominal de 32,500.000 francs, divisè an 325,000 Actions ordinaires de 100 francs, doit être, par rèduction des deux tiers, remanè a 10,833,400 francs, divisè en 108,334 Actions ordinaires. Une Action nouvelle doit être remise en èchange de trois anciennes.

En outre, aux termes du concordat votè par l'Assemblèe des crèanciers, le 23 Mai 1906, et homologuè par judgement du Tribunal mixte du Caire, le 2 Juin suivant, les 102,405 obligations ordinaires de 500 francs 4% restant en circulation doivent être èchangèes contre de nouvelles obligations ordinaires de 400 Fcs. remboursables a 500 francs en 60 ans, a revenu variable, maximum 5% avec èchèance du 1 Juillet 1909 pour le premier coupon.

Au moment de l'èchange des obligations, les pouters pourront demander l'èchange pur et simple ou l'èchange avec l'estampille donnant droit a un coupon annuel de 8 francs, pendant 3 ans, payable par semestre, pour le premier paiement qui doit avoir lieu le 1 Juillet 1906, et ce aux charges et conditionnes de l'article 3 du concordat.
L'option pour l'estampille des Titres prend fin le 31 Dècembre 1906.
Les porteurs des Titres (Actions et Obligations) pourront les dèposer, a partir de ce jour, contre un recul provisoire a èchangar ultèrieurement contra les nouveaux Titres.

div.head: NILE GAUGE READINGS
div.p: SEPTEMBER 1905-1906

div.head: LETTERS FROM EGYPT
div.p: 2,000 YEARS AGO.

Letters posted B.C., wherein we yet can read, between the lines, aye, gauge the writers mood as he bit the end of his writing reed in meditative pause, and sum up his character— so very human were those vanished scribes, whose missives, nevertheless, yet live, to prove how very much alike is all this common clay, mere crocks, good, bad, and indifferent, fashioned as the wheel turns order the Great Potter's hand.

To deal, then, with those from the land o the Nile. A "Tommy" serving in the army of one of the Pharaohs unbosoms himself to his mother thus: "Can't she send him more of the needful? Without, however, letting his father know this time (!). He hates drawing upon her housekeeping allowance - in fact, it makes him feel awfully bad—but at the same time, what is a fellow to do? The governor shouldn't keep him so short, that is the crux of the matter. It seems all the more inexcusable, too, considering his father himself had at one time served in the army, and might therefore, be reasonably expected to know that no fellow can live on his pay, seeing the expenses he is continually being put to. You can't keep out of everything; if you did you'd only get sneered at by the other men in your regiment, many of whom, in our friend case, are the sons of very wealthy parents." He therefore suggests that on the next favourable occasion the mater shall try her well known powers of persuasion on behalf of her loving son. unless she wishes to see him over head and ears in debt—a state of things he feels sure she would move heaven and earth to avert thus ends this epistle, and we, for our part, have no doubt whatever that this unknown Egyptian mother did thousands of years ago exactly what a mother does, and shielded her boy, whether he deserved it or not, from the wrath of the father who had forgotten what it was to be young.

Another young hopeful from the provinces, evidently destined for commerce and apprenticed to some thriving house of business, writes to his mother, a widow woman: Will she be so good as to send him a pair of leather breeches, and that speedily. Also, a set of new shirts, the last dear mother wove for him having gone the way of all shirts, some being reduced to a state past praying for, and others lost in the wash. And at the end of this effusion he begs his fond parent to remember and make this new set larger in the neck, the last having left something to be desired in the matter of fit generally. (Evidently the provincial shirt of Egypt lacked the smart cut affected in the metropolis.)

Still another missive from the lead of the Sphinx a "cri du ceceur'' this time— hinting at piquant "on dits" and a tactfully averted scandal. Here we have an absent spouse writing in evident trepidation to the wife of his bosom who bides at home at a safe distance. How much does she know, and how much doesn't she? We cast our mind's eye back over those odd thousand of years and seem to see him busily tracing hurried and flurried hieroglyphics upon the scroll, only to be irritably torn up again and a fresh reed and more papyrus called for. Then he makes a fresh start. Business detains him longer than he had anticipated, scrawls he, but his dear wife is to give no attention to the evil tongues of men, who, he understands, have been busy coupling his came with that of a certain fair temple dancer, saying that he, her faithfullest and ownest one, had been having his portrait painted for the hussy, forsooth! Now, this is how it stands and thee the poor man, so sorely put to it, goes on to explore the fact that this portrait ordered had been for the temple, not for the vestal maid on duty there, Nor was it a portrait of him, nor devoted lord, but a picture of his late lamented father, whom tomb this dutiful son had, to his chagrin, found was devoid of so necessary an adjunct to the mortuary chamber of persons of rank. He had, therefore, hastened to make good the overnight idle tongue. Tut, tut! She was, however, to give it no further thought, but he of good cheer; and, furthermore, he calmed her a string of pearls, to solace her for his continued absence, hoped to be back soon, sent kisses to the children, etc, etc. A very pretty story, and a plausible. This Egyptian husband was evidently quite an adapt at patting the thing nicely, and we me only hope that for his sake he managed to wriggle out of this fix with no more than a cold sweat such rumors have landed the mere man "A.D." in remarkably tight corners before now. Besides, "temple dancers," too- him! Madame's reply, we note, has not survived; it was probably given verbally, and lost nothing for the keeping.

div.head: ENGLAND'S 10,000 MOTORS
div.p: It is stated that the outlook in the motor car world is not of the brighter for French manufacturers. They are beginning to feel somewhat severely the pinch of international competition. This year the season has been rather dull, and it is certainly not going to improve (says the "Telegraph's Paris correspondent) before the big show in December.

Foreign competitors, especially the Italians, are said to have completed, or are completing. arrangements for a vastly increased output, and it is further reported in Paris that England intends next year to produce 10,000 cars, all of which has considerably perturbed the French makers. It is by no means unlikely that the December salon will see a sharp cut in prices.

div.head: RAW COTTON.
div.p: RECORD AMERICAN OUTPUT.

During the fiscal year just concluded America has exported raw cotton to the value of rather over £80,000,000 which easily constitutes a world's record, exceeding the export of iron and steel manufactures by £47,800,000, bread stuffs of all kinds by £49,800,000, and provisions by £37,800,000. Prior to 1901 the exports amounted to less than £60,000,000 thus in five years the trade has increased by more than 5O per cent. It was in the yer of 1866 that the value of the exports totaled for the first time £40,000,000, so that for similar advance as has occurred during the past five years it previously took over thirty years to accomplish. The remarkable increase since 1901 is not altogether owing to the larger quantity exported, but is partly the result of the increase in price. The exports during 1906 were actually 700,000,000lb. less than luring 1903, while the value of the smaller amount was more them £4,000,000 greater.

Not only was 1906 a record year so far as the exportation of raw cotton was concerned, but manufactured cotton to the extent of £10,500,000 was sold to foreign countries compared with £10,000,000 in 1905. The advance over last year, therefore, is not very striking, but when compered with 1904 the increase is remarkable, when only £4,500,000 was received from abroad. Before the year 1877 the exports of mmanufactured cotton goods had always been below £2,000,000 with one exception, and it was not until twenty years later that they amounted to £4,000,000, while by 1902, a period of only five years, they had increased to over £6,000,000, and by 1905 to £10,000,000. The increase in manufactured goods is therefore equally remarkable as in the case of the raw material, and it probably unique in the history of the export trade of any country.

Nearly all the raw cotton produced in America is disposed of in Europe, out of the total value of the exports of£80,000,000 the various countries of Europe having taken no less than £76,500,000. Of this amount the United Kingdom absorbed £35,400,000. Germany £20,200,000, France £9,000000, and Italy £5,400,000 while the remaining countries took about £6,500,000. During 1906 Japan took about £1,500,000,a reduction of £2,000,000 over the preceding year, but an increase of £1,000,000 over 1904.

From the total of £10,500,000, the value of the export of manufactured cotton goods,China absorbed very nearly £6,000,000. China takes an enormous quantity of cotton clothes, the value imported from America last year being £5,928,237, while other cotton goods amounted t only £34,577. There was a market increase in the value of cotton exported to China last year, exceeding 1905 by about £400,000. The quantity, too, was greatly in excess of the preceding year, amounting to no less than 24,000,000yd. During the fiscal year of 1906 America exported in all 711,000,000yd. of cotton cloth, of which 498,000,000 went to China, 183,000,000 to South America, and 25,000,000 to Asia, other than China

div.head: MALARIA RAVAGES IN GREECE.
div.p: Professor Dr. Savas, of Athens University, and vice president of the Greek Anit-Malaria League, was entertained to luncheon at Liverpool University Club last week Sir Alfred Jones, chairman of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine. Sir Alfred Jones, unable through indisposition to attend, was represented by the Lord Mayor of Liverpool, and the guests included leading citizens, scientists, and members of the Greek community.

Professor Ronald Ross detailed his investigations carried out in Greece four months ago, and described the ravages wrought by malaria in that historic country. With a population of only two and a half million, Greece, he said, had two hundred and fifty thousand cases of malaria and seventeen hundred and sixty deaths annually from the disease which was continually sapping the vitality of the nation. The success achieved in Ismailia, Havana, and the Campagna proved the possibility of abolishing the disease by clearing the swamps which constituted the breeding place for the malaria breaking gnats, and this was the work before them in Greece. Princess Christian headed the list of British supporters of the Grecian movement, and be appeared for generous support to clear the whole of Greece from the terrible scourge of malaria.

div.head: A GREEK TRAGEDY
div.p: A terrible family drama has just been enacted in the Greek village of Menidi, not far from Athens. A youth named Michas, betrothed to a girl named Varellas, developed wild habits which ended in his killing a gendarme and being sentenced to seven years' penal servitude, which ended recently. Meantime, his fiancee's parents, naturally deeming that their daughter's engagement was cancelled, permitted her to marry a more respectable suitor. For this Mochas swore vengeance, which he found means to execute on the occasion of a country visit. His former fiancee and her husband, with the families on both sides, had gone and were returning up a wild hillside, where Michas lay in waiting with a rifle. The only two men of the party were shot, and two women, one of them the girl who was the innocent cases of the tragedy. When found her body, besides the bullet wound, was found to bear 10 stabs. The murderer escaped.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: THE CAIRO PRESS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,- In these latter days the world "is going to the dogs" to use a homely but very expressive English expression. One might add to this that Egypt is going fast to the pigeons- Denishwai at that- real wild birds that are only appreciated at their true worth by certain shameless printed at their true worth by certain shameless printed sheets that presume to call themselves journals. We have known for a long time that England has ceased going to the dogs. She has already arrived.

These statements are too axiomatic to need proof. If any were needed it would suffice only to read the noisy Egyptian Press. Then too, an individual, a person, a really blunt person has told the world so.
It is not my purpose in these few lines to abuse anyone, least of all those eminent exponents of Egyptian thought so recently returned from aboard.

Anyone with a piaster to spare, sufficiently good eyesight, and a faculty for deciphering execrable print can read in a Cairo morning journal a fact that quietly-disposed people will receive with surprise. We are told that the Denishwai affairs is not closed. It is useless to ask why. There it is written, and the pen that wrote the words knew the whole story. It is left to be inferred that if this oracle had not returned to Egypt in the nick of times, as it were, the affair would have certainly died- if not a natural and quiet death, at least a premature one. No one will think of questioning the decision of this intuitive writer. It is practically known that he has received inside information. I would suggest from- No, On Second thoughts I will not suggest anything. It is not the purpose of this article to "suggest," Like "Anthony" of Trumphirate fame. "WE are here to speak that which we do know."

We know, for instance how smallness flourishes at the expense of the Great. We know that more things are bought and sold in Egypt than even Egypt dreams of. Again we know that certain Cairo so called journals are terribly hard up for decent "copy." We know many more things, granting always of course that there are many things we don't know. To resume, we know that if the shrieking rabble of puenibe, that for the past three months has not left the Egyptian newspaper buying public a quiet moment in respect of this tiresome Denishawi incident, represents Egyptian opinion, then Egypt is ungrateful, then the good that great nations do is truly and effectively buried with the passing seasons; and fair Egypt, mislead Egypt, is turning against the hand that has always sought to help her.

But I do not believe that Egypt is ungrateful. It does not require more than a farthing's worth of common sense (most uncommon by the way in Cairo at present) to see that the whole of the present agitation, beginning at the bottom with M. Kamel Pasha, is a striving for effect, for notoriety, for the sake of something to do, and in a few well-marked cases for something else. It is rather a pity that Egyptian writers can find no other topic for their pens than one that has long been worn threadbare. No one of course is foolish enough to suppose that Egyptian writers represent Egyptian opinion or Egyptian sentiment. Egyptian journals and journalists with one or two fine exceptions are organs and men who have, what? An axe to grind, a foible to exploit, a bad and foolish dream to immortalize in a wretched print on worse paper, or some useful institution to snarl at and misinterpret. Therefore it is that the Egyptian writer such as he is must be disassociated from his journal and his capacity of journalist. In the one case he is a being of ratiocinator powers; in the other he is something hired to shriek at so much per shriek.

The fault of the Egyptian Press- granting that there is such a thing, and in case real proof can be adduced in support of the fact, that the Egyptian Press is sincere- the fault is that it is parochial. Its sense of proportions is inverted. Its idea of the fitness of things is hopelessly distorted. One would suppose that England's destiny began and would end with Denishwaia few mud houses seven miles from nowhere in particular. Egypt herself- bag and baggage is, I believe, on an average mentioned once a year in the English House of Commons. One is apt to forget in the valley of the Nile that England does not, as the saying goes "actually lie awake at night thinking of the attacks of the Egyptian Press, that her policy is not designed after proofs by "The Lea", and that her Ministers are not affected in the slightest degree by the frenzy of the "blunt" Individual, hereinbefore mentioned.

It is in the times of discussion over an affair like Denishwait when soberness and judgment should be displayed that persons like Mr. Blunt, or whatever his name is, feel themselves impelled to give their nothing to a non- expectant public. The real cause behind such vaporings is, may it be presumed, ascribable to the dysentery that is now so prevalent.

Let it be assumed that there was a point of law or procedure involved in the disposal of the Denishwai case that did not conform to what Monsieur "The man in the street" thought should have been allowed. That signifies nothing. The Regulation legalizing the Denishwai Tribunal is in intent and purpose a Statute of Egyptian Law. There only remains then a difference of opinion as to the harshness and necessity of the sentence imposed. It should not be forgotten that great forces always appear cruel, and that the life of one or of a hundred men are of no account in the interworking of a world-embracing foreign policy. Egyptians (and here let us stretch a point and include the so-called National Party) must realize this fact: Nature has placed Egypt in a geographical position that gives her and her affairs a far more than intrinsic interest. She can never be considered alone; and even her interests may at some time or another have to give place to those of greater magnitude and to the dictates of a foreign policy with which she has nothing to do. Egypt is, and never will be more than, a pawn on the international chessboard. May the people, the real Egyptian people, learn then this lesson. Their liberty must be bound up with a greater liberty; as a nation their destinies must always be shaped from outside by powers whose might Egypt can never hope to overcome. Let them not throw lightly away the good she has thus far received nor follow blindly the host of fond and false prophets with which the cafes and boulevards of her cities swarm, lest perchance a worse thing come upon her.
Moderation
Cairo, Septemer 25.

div.head: ECONOMY AND EFFICIENCY
div.p: Lord Kitchener, the type of the modern organizer, who defeated the Dervishes with his transport and his commissariat service, has once more justified his reputation in India. He hates waste, not so much for the burden it imposes upon the taxpayers as for the inefficiency which it produces in the service. It is the custom in the Army, as in most other departments, to accelerate expenditure as the end of the financial year approaches. The supplies are specifically voted and allotted for one year only, and men who enjoy the luxury of expending public money without having the responsibility for its collection do not like to have an "unspent balance" at the end of the year.-
"Morning Leader."
